headline: Best Roast Beef
description: Learn how to cook a roast beef without drying it out with this easy method! Tender, juicy, melt-in-your-mouth roast beef is perfect for holidays or special family dinners.

video.description: Tying the roast, and cooking at high heat, ensure even roasting.
video.name: All-American Roast Beef

name: Best Roast Beef
recipeIngredient: 3 pounds beef eye of round roast, at room temperature
0.5 teaspoon kosher salt, or more to taste
0.5 teaspoon garlic powder, or more to taste
0.25 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper, or more to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
Make sure roast is at room temperature. Tie roast at 3-inch intervals with cotton twine; this helps it from drying out and allows it to cook more evenly. Place roast on a rack in a baking pan.
Mix together salt, garlic powder, and pepper in a small bowl. Rub seasoning mixture into the meat.

Place in the preheated oven and roast for 60 minutes, or 20 minutes per pound if your roast is larger or smaller. An instant-read thermometer inserted into the center should read 120 to 125 degrees F (49 to 52 degrees C).
Remove from the oven and transfer to a cutting board. Cover loosely with foil, and let rest so juices can redistribute, 15 to 20 minutes.

review.reviewBody: One of the best roasts ever! Very tender and cooking times were perfect.
I usually add another 15 minutes to cooking time to make just 'pinkish' instead of medium rare.
Went exactly by directions. Came out tougher than my shoe leather! Had trouble cutting it with knife. Should be cooked in slow cooker, long and slow.
Pretty close to fool proof & basic

After decades of doing it this way, I recently learned a simple trick that makes it even better... First, coat the entire roast with olive oil, then season. You can also do it on charcoal or gas grill this way. For one with temp control, set at 400 and give it a quarter turn every 12-15 minutes depending on thickness. Perfect!
So simple and yet brought back many memories of Sunday dinners with the family.
Great recipe and very easy
Only thing was I did not have powdered garlic powder, used fresh crushed garlic. Great recipe, my son loved it!
Use a top sirloin roast. Perfect!
Quick, easy, delicious
Actually this is just how my mother made roast beef a generation ago. Same cut of meat, same temperature and time per pound. Serviceable but not outstanding.
This was the best roast beef I have ever made. It was delicious.
Really good. Added red wine to bottom of pan for the Au Jus. Center came out just how I like it!

Followed the directions and added a bit of water and onions to the bottom of the pan and this turned out great! The roast was juicy and easy to pull off in a short amount of time. It is a lean piece of beef so thin slices is best!
I absolutely loved this recipe. This will be in my family favorites for sure.
Came out perfect.
Perfect every time I've made this. Very pleased.

Added about 1 cup broth to bottom. Dredged roast in flour with seasonings mixed in. Took closer to 25 minutes per lb for 120 degrees, at which time I took out of oven to tent. Microwaved potatoes and carrots to cook them a bit more while roast rested. Very tender !
Such an easy recipe! It came out perfect! Very juicy , one of the best roasts I ever made! Thank you!
Perfect roast!

Terrific recipe & method! Our 2lb Eye roast had a very thin layer of fat on top. It was dried it with a paper towel, sat on the counter for about 10 minutes and then was placed in a roasting pan with a rack. A very small amount of olive oil was used to lightly coat the roast. Seasonings patted all over the roast: salt, pepper, garlic powder, onion powder, thyme and herbs de provence. Roasted at 375 for 1 hour and 20 min until meat thermometer read 140. Thank you for the comments about checking the meat temperature! We have an old oven so it took longer than expected. The meat temp is the key, don't rely on the timing. Covered and rested for about 15-20 min then sliced thin. Delicious, and very tender. The drippings were minimal so if gravy is wanted it does need doctoring up a bit for flavor. The meat itself was delicious! Thanks for sharing!
Oh my! This is so easy and wonderful! It us now my go to recipe!
Yum!!!
Doubled the seasoning, love the recipe
Love this recipe. It is my go to when preparing meals for a large crowd.

It's a fairly good recipe, but all I'm going to say is it is a good thing I had a meat thermometer. I followed the instructions and cooked my two pound roast 20 minutes, per pound, 40 minutes total, as per instructed, and my roast was completely cold in the middle! Not even close to being cooked. It took another 40 minutes to reach the 135° at 375°. Otherwise, it was reasonably tasty. Next time I will probably cook at a lower temperature for a longer period of time though. I find it makes for a much more tender of a roast.

I doubled the seasoning has I had two different roasts to cook. I seasoned all the sides. I did add a little water to the pan. I cooked it at 375 as directed. The flavor was really good. Typically I just use salt and pepper. The garlic was a really nice addition. I plan to make all my future roasts like this. I do recommend adding a bit of water though. If you buy roasts low in fat you will need additional liquid. Also it gives you more liquid to use for gravy. YUM

I love salt, pepper and garlic as the inky spices. The outside is very yummy. The issue we have had is that we started our first one with the 20 mins/ pound timing and it came out mostly raw which 4/5 of us did not like. So we made. A second time with 22 mins/ pound and it still came out very rare. The third time we did 25 mins/ pound and it was rare at the ends about an inch in then raw middle. We can’t seem to get the timing down right so it’s rare in the middle vs. raw. Tasty but if people don’t like very bloody meat, you need to cook it significantly longer.
Great way to cook roast beef.
My family loved it.

In the Top 3 of roast beef dinners ever tried in the home kitchen.
Basic and easy to follow instructions. Didn’t use garlic powder due to personal preference but still a winner, none the less!

I followed the recipe exactly and it was not cooked long enough. I cooked it 15 minutes longer and it was still not cooked or tender. Had to add it to a stew for another night. Would NOT recommend. Going back to making it in my crockpot so it's tender.
I followed the tips from Tracycook. Take out of oven at 120 degrees and let it sit for 20 min and served at 130 135. My first time making a roast came out perfect!
Fantastic for a nice meal
I used instead of the spices listed. Mrs. Grass beef and onion soup dry mix plus carrots, celery, onion and potatoes.

Very good. My supermarket is now offering Prime cuts of roasts so it’s perfection. Super tender. I add onion powder and celery salt to taste in addition to the garlic, salt and pepper. Then I make au jus on the side.

My grandmother made this often in the 1960’s-1970’s so this reminds me of my childhood :) 
Follow cooking time and temp ! I wanted to cook it more but glad I did not !! It was not dry . I also made 4 holes in the top of roast and placed a garlic clove in each one . Grandma did that, so I followed her lead ! 
I will make again,
Thank you
Excellent. I used twine to truss my roast to an even size, and placed it on a small wire rack while roasting on the convection setting. followed the recipe as written. Perfect.

I made a 5 pound roast for Easter dinner. Everyone loved it, but it took much longer to cook than the 20 minutes per pound. I cooked it in foil for the recommended time and it was not even rare. I turned the temperature up to 400 degrees and added 60 minutes and it turned out perfectly. (Well). Very tender. I served it with sautéed onions and gravy and there were not a lot of leftovers. I will definitely make this again, it’s super easy, cleanup is easy and it’s really really good.
This recipe was straight up magic. I didn't even tie my roast. Trust it. My roast was the most perfect medium rare and juicy I wanted to cry. Best piece of beef I've ever cooked. Amazing.

Incredibly simple recipe for an inexpensive cut of meat. I followed suggestions by others and doubled the amount of seasonings and added some thyme and onion powder. Used a thermometer to cook it to 125, then covered with foil and let it sit for 20 minutes while I prepared the rest of dinner. Will definitely make it again.

Perfect! I did make a few changes. I was fortunate enough to have herb de Provence so I mixed a 1/4 cup of softened butter with 1 teaspoon of herb de Provence, and on teaspoon of black pepper. Lathered the meat with it and applied a generous amount of kosher salt. I was using a convection oven set to roast so cut the temperature down to 350 degrees. The timing was pretty accurate. but I use it only as a guide. The internal temperature rose to a little more than I like. I usually roast to 120 degrees, but went to 126. I let it rest for 15 minutes tented, and when cut was a beautiful pink. I had a very lean eye of round, but there were enough drippings to make a wonderful au jous. I added some red wine to the sauce. I don't use flour in my au jous for I feel that is gravy. not au jous. Reduced it, and the dinner was just spectacular.

Must have the beef at room temp. This was so easy and I'm a hero for making it for dinner. If you have picky beef eaters because it used to "dry" out , this will be the best they've had. Crock pot does all the work , you get the love.
Easy Peasy... and turned out delicious.
I made this for Sunday's supper, and it came out perfectly medium rare, which my family loves! I added garlic mashed potatoes, green beans, salad, and mushroom gravy.
Perfect recipe to make a good impression easily. I pretty much make it whenever eyeround goes on sale since it’s so easy! I’m all about high impact, low effort recipes

2.13.19 Well, the reviews are all over the place, so I decided to totally follow the recipe. My roast weighed 2.75 pounds, I cooked at 375ºF for 50 minutes at which time my thermometer was reading 140º, so I removed it from the oven, and let it sit covered with foil for 15 minutes before slicing. Although the meat was perfectly cooked, it was tough as shoe leather. And I’m not faulting the recipe for this because I’m finding more and more often, it’s the meat itself, not necessarily the cooking method. We still enjoyed it even though we did a lot more chewing. To finish off the leftovers, I made roast beef hash one evening, and some open-faced roast beef sandwiches another. After the thinly-sliced beef simmered in the hot gravy for a while, it did soften a bit. I’m almost to the point where I’m about ready to give up roasting beef, because one time it’s tender and the next time with the same recipe, it’s tough. This inconsistency drives me nuts because it’s always “hit or miss.”
This was very good. The timing was perfect!
I cooked it in the oven roaster but other than that I followed the recipe exactly as it was written. Very tender!

Omg. I let the meat sit out to come to room temperature and it was still raw! So gross. Either your idea of cooked meat is way different than mine or my oven is way off. I will buy an oven thermometer tomorrow. If there’s nothing wrong with my oven, then there is something really wrong with this recipe.
Followed the original recipe and came out perfectly!

Perfection!! I used a 9.5lb tenderloin, rubbed it with Mrs. Dash Garlic and Herb spices to save time. It was delicious even though I forgot to add the salt just before convection baking for 3 hours. Next time, I will remember that to see what the difference is. I found this recipe while searching for a "Perfection Roast" recipe where you cook for 5 minutes(?) per pound on 500 then keep the oven doors shut for 2 hours. I couldn't find that specific one, so I tried this and am extremely pleased. Not being stressed at all about it was a bonus!
simple easy and yummy
Pleased

20 minutes per pound worked for me! I rubbed olive oil on it before I seasoned it with garlic salt, sea salt, black pepper and garlic powder. I didn't measure those, I used generously. A meat thermometer is your best friend. I took it out at 130 and covered it with aluminum. 20 minutes later, it was 140....PERFECT

It got the job done. Next time I will cut the time down to about 15min per pound. When I took it out of the oven it was already at 165 so quite overcooked for my liking. Also added some beef stock to bottom of the roasting pan before putting in the oven so we could make gravy from the drippings. Good starter recipe, though, and very easy.
Roast turned out great. Followed the directions, (20 minutes a lb.) I inserted 2 garlic cloves into the roast for extra flavor.
Great taste and very tender.

I seasoned the roast (skipped the pepper and added ground orgeano) and let it sit in the refrigerator overnight. I tied the roast and place in the peheated oven and cooked 20 mins per pound. I removed from the oven with 5 minutes left on the timer. I removed the roast from the rack and wrapped it in foil and let it sit for 1 hour before tasting it. When I unwrapped it there was about 1/4 cup of jus under the roast. I cut the strings and turned the roast, and wrapped it again. 2 hours later we had super tender and VERY tasty roast. Used the jus to make gravy.

I made this as written but did use a meat thermometer as recommended by previous reviewers and I used more seasonings. I let it sit to room temp before putting it in the oven. When it reached the temp I wanted, I took it out, covered it with foil, and let it sit for 20 min. This was the best roast beef I have ever made! I sliced it thin and it was so juicy that I had to keep draining my cutting board. My husband loved it too! I've added it to my favorites.
Basic and great flavor
Great Recipe!!! Done to perfection!!!

It may have just been the quality of the roast. Nolan Ryan shoulder roast. This was super easy and turned out rare, tender and flavorful. I always like to use lots of fresh cracked pepper. I did marinate it for about 3hrs in grapefruit juice, soy sauce and Worcestershire.

I have a newly calibrated oven. I followed the recipe exactly- brought the meat to room temperature, (20 minutes per pound at 375 degrees. The roast was raw and the temperature didn't even register on my brand new meat thermometer. VERY disappointed.

Followed instructions for recipe and it was really good. we'll probably end up doing our own mix of spices for the outside but overall the meat was juicy and delicious! Whoever said theirs was dry did it wrong!

Followed suggestions regarding cooking in lower temperature as we like our roast beef medium rare (closer to rare than medium), and it turned out amazing. My husband said it was one of the best roasts he ever had. Thanks for the recipe :)

This is a great way to make a very moist and delicious roast. People saying cook slow and in liquid are dead wrong. You can get a very dry roast while cooking in liquid. (Thats the way my mom cooked them all my life) The only thing I do different is I sear the roast on all sides in a stainless steel or iron skillet then put the skillet into the oven straightaway. Shortens cooking time by about 8 to 10 min. Great recipe!

I used to cook roast beef the way my mom did, with onions, carrots and potatoes in the pan, and (no offense Mom) but it was not my favorite thing - always dry, chewy beef. I think she put water in the roasting pan. 

Then I tried this recipe. I love it! So simple, and the beef comes out tender, deliciously flavoured and mouthwatering! Mmmmmmm. 
Where's the beef? In my oven right now! :)

This is a Great recipe ! I doubled the spices, but cooked it exactly as directed. It was delicious! The family loved it! This recipe is a definite keeper! All the people that said that they needed to add liquid to the pan are crazy! I didn't add Any liquid to my pan and after I let the roast sit for 20 minutes there was plenty of natural juices in the pan for me to make an au jus sce as well! 
PERFECT RECIPE AS IS! ( my family prefer a lot of flavor, so I doubled the seasonings)
omitted salt, used ground blk pepper, garlic powder, smokey paprika

This recipe and method worked perfectly. I cooked two separate cuts as I had a few more people to serve. Both weighed 2.5 lbs and I kept it in the oven for 1hr and 10min. It came out perfectly juicy and just the right amount of tenderness. This is one of my first dishes I’ve cooked on my own and it worked to perfection and to everyone’s expectations!

I was very skeptical about roasting beef at 375 degree for 20 minutes per pound. Followed recipe as written, figuring cook time exactly for 3.68 lb roast. Wow! Came out perfectly medium rare which is exactly how I like it. Will follow this method from now on.

My mother used to make a roast this way. It was like a Manhattan roast beef. Sometimes she would get extra suet from the butcher and lay it on top of the roast. As the suet melted it added and extra layer of beefy richness so important for good gravy fixings. Then, of course she discarded the suet when the roast was done.

Decided to try this as I didn't have the time to use a slow cooker. I was very pleased with the seasoning and cooking time suggestion was dead on. However the meat was tough despite a few reviews suggesting it wouldn't be.

As soon as I got it on the cutting board and tried to cut a slice was when I noticed and thought my knife was dull so I sharpened it and still it was very tough for a fresh knife. Now when we started eating everyone had one complaint, was very tough (even for restraunt steak knives.

I cooked it on a rack to keep it off the roast pan. Probably should of had beef broth in the bottom.

It is great recipe. The only thing I would do next time, put less salt. When I saw 4 tsp of salt, I put only 3. It was still salty. I had 3.5 lb NY streep. I Cooked at 350 Fr for 30 min, meat temperature reached to 120 Fr, added another 10 min, meat temperature reached to 140 Fr. The ends were well done, in the middle it was medium - rear. It was perfect.

yes, I will make this again!! I agree it can be a little tough if you don't follow the time per pound and don't add gravy or seasoned water to it. But, overall it is quick and easy dinner in the week or weekend supper for the family! My husband loved it!!!:) Sometimes it was a juicy sandwich between bread and you can add a baked potato or mashed potatoes with it.

I wasn't sure what cut of beef it was that I dug out of the freezer, but these instructions worked wonders on it anyway. (Might have been a chuck shoulder...) Thanks to whoever posted this, basic as it may be.

I made it with a couple simple changes. I chopped red potatoes and rolled them in olive oil and garlic salt in the bottom of the pan. Before cooking I layered the top of the roast with onions and center cut bacon. The bacon grease basted the roast while cooking so it wouldn't dry and the excess grease kept the potatoes nice and moist. I also put a half a cup of water in the bottom of the pan before i started. I cooked to 145 in the oven and let it finish on the counter at 150 before slicing. Rave reviews from all the guests at my dinner party! Let the roast sit to room temperature on the counter before you start for nice even cooking.

6lb. roast, cooked it for an hour and forty minutes... the rub was so tasty... turned out perfectly juicy and kids even liked it. Side of garlic mashed potatoes with steamed green peas and smothered it all in 'canned' brown gravy... doesn't get any better!
this was a great and simple recipe , I sliced it thin and made some great French dip sandwiches with it

I love the ease and idea of this recipe but I guess even with a new gas oven it doesn't fully work. My 2 1/2 lb eye of round roast was rare, not medium-rare and cold when I followed the directions. It was very tender though and I was making a cauliflower rice dish as a side dish so I just stir fried the beef to medium and added it to the rice and thus was pleased with the final product.
I'll be playing with this to see how to make it work for my oven. I have a 'keep warm' setting that I may try or simply turn the oven down to the lowest temp it has. Thanks for the great idea, now I'll work to make it fit my oven.
Did timing according to directions and meat was raw practicality had to put back in oven while rest of meal was done! 2.5lbs at 60m at 375. 20 minutes under loose foil too!

Made this twice now. Taste was good for an easy quick meal. I removed roast from the oven when internal temp reached 135 F and let it rest. Result was a good medium rare, with external slices being more along the lines of medium-well doneness. 2nd time making eye of round I changed the recipe a bit to try making italian beef, added herbs and more seasoning, let roast rest as I did before. Then, wrapped roast in foil and placed in fridge for 24 hours. Result was easy for slicing, but next time I'll remove from oven at 120 F to reach rare doneness after the rest time. If you use this meat to make Chicago Italian Beefs with your own au jus, ya gotta do a rare temp since the slices of meat will be placed in the jus and finish cooking. Anything above rare cook time would result in over cooked beefs--no one likes rubbery italian beefs--that's my opinion anyway. 5 stars for good, basic recipe as written with proper cooking time. Loved being able to follow cook temp in this recipe for da beefs! If only I could master the jus for the beefs, but that's a whole other recipe!

I would definitely make it again. I used steak seasoning and paprika. I made gravy to go with it and mixed in the juices from the beef as recommended by the recipe. It was easy to make and my family loved it.

This is a winner. I had a 3 1/2 pound roast cooked it for 75 minutes. I seasoned it heavily. I did take the suggestion of others and inserted garlic in the roast. It was perfect, not bloody, just pink in the middle.

I added 2 cups of water to the bottom of the pan with a Knorr's beef cube. I put the 3 lb roast on a rack (sprayed with Pam) and cooked it for 20 minutes per lb.. (1 hour) and it was RAW. Seriously. I cooked it another hour and it was still rare. I don't understand why you would only cook it for 1 hour. The seasoning was a bit too much... I wouldn't measure the salt, pepper and garlic powder again, I'd just sprinkle it on. So I would say this was not a good recipe for me.
How would you use this in a slow cooker as I like mine better than the oven more tender Thanks All for the help??

The real beauty of this recipe is the simplicity. The oven does most of the work. The key is not to over cook and to let the roast rest, as it will continue to cook. The only change I made was adding the same ratio of pepper to the salt and garlic. Combine all in a little bowl and then rub on the meat. Note: ensure you buy the correct cut of meat.
Followed instructions exactly. Roast was too well done. I was trying for medium rare. I will attempt this again...
Perfect the way it is. I had to search a bit for this recipe because I kept getting pot-roasts... not what I was after
Simple and delicious every time. No mods needed.
I don’t normally rate meals, but I had to try and balance out at least one of the 1-star reviews that are upset because this isn’t a pot roast.

Made this for dinner tonight.......holy yum!!! Anyone that has had problems with it being tough,the key is letting it sit covered & check with a meat thermometer. Made roasted carrots, peas and roasted garlic mashed potatoes & gravy to go along with it.
comes out great everytime
Excellent !!!
Followed it exactly and all I know is that I've been making it all wrong for years. I'm in love!
I have been making my roast beef ,this way for many years. It comes out delicious. The only thing do differently is add soy sauce,in which I pour over the whole roast beef to marinate.

Came out perfect. Exactly the right temp and timing per pound for people who like rare to medium rare. Yum. Sitting the roast out for 20 mins at room temperature prior to cooking is also something I have learned before cooking (passed down from my French Mom).
Worked for us! We added some paprika, just cause.
